justification: “Participants were presented with a single word … and asked to indicate whether it was alive or not by pressing the 'F' or 'J' key… All participants responded to all 140 words.”
“For the familiarity task, participants were asked to rate '…how familiar you are with each word'… participants were presented with a sliding scale representing 0-100.”

“For the imageability task, participants were asked to rate '…how easy each thing is to visualise'… The scale had ticks at 0, 25, 50, 75, 100 with the labels 'extremely difficult' … 'extremely easy'.”
“Participants answered eight questions relating to how each item was able to move, shown in Table 2… Each word was shown … with a series of sliders underneath for the questions.”

“We also queried the motor-relevance of objects by asking about how easy items were to manipulate. … question 5: ‘How easy is it for you to pick up and move this thing?’ (0: immobile … 100: easily moveable).”

“First, there was an open text box and participants were asked to 'type any words that you can remember from the experiment'. They were not informed in advance that they would be asked to recall the words.”
